subject: Re: NEW Object instance
msgSnippet: Since the constructor takes two parameters, it must do something with them. I would test that it actually does what it should with them. If it sets member
messageBody:
Since the constructor takes two parameters, it must do something
with them. I would test that it actually does what it should with
them. If it sets member variables, were they set, etc.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "teemu kanstren" <tkanstren@...> wrote:
>
> 2006/5/10, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...>:
> >
> > >
> > > Let's assume you have class MyClass with a constructor that
accepts 2
> > > parameters. As far as I know, the easiest way to test object
creation
> > > is:
> > >
> > > public void testCreation () {
> > > MyClass obj = new MyClass(param1, param2);
> > > assertNotNull(obj);
> > > }
> >
> > This test can never fail, so why write it?
> >
>
> I think it could fail if the constructor threw an exception :). I
don't see
> how the assertion would fail though. Nor do I think it would be a
good test
> but I guess that depends on what you write in the constructors of
you
> classes I guess.
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>
